data.title: Things to Do in Naxos, Greece: An Epic Roadtrip Itinerary
data.meta_description: The bigger, chiller Naxos provides a great contrast to touristy Santorini. Here are the top things to see in Naxos, Greece, an amazing roadtrip itinerary!
data.text:
Putting together a Greek island-hopping itinerary is a bit nervewracking, because there are so many amazing islands to choose from. Even once you narrow down to the Cyclades, you‚Äôre spoiled for choice. But I‚Äôm here to tell you that the island of Naxos‚Äîand specifically a Naxos roadtrip‚Äîneeds to be on your itinerary!

From the ruins of ancient temples and Venetian castles that rise above the delightfully jumbled streets of the towns, to the sparkling turquoise waters and long sandy beaches, Naxos is a hidden gem that is less crowded and more affordable than its famous sisters of Santorini and Mykonos.

Because it is often overlooked and is also the biggest island in the Cyclades, you can plan a super diverse Naxos itinerary and feel like you have the island to yourself. Hike among Byzantine churches, olive groves, and goat farms. Chill on a golden sandy beach surrounded by a cedar forest. Chow down on fresh seafood and surprisingly-great cocktails in what has become a bit of a foodie destination.

You might also like: My Favorite Cross-Body Purse for Travel

For me, Naxos was a welcome respite from the crowds of Santorini‚Ä¶very chill, with some of the best beaches in the Cyclades, turquoise waters, and whitewashed buildings as well as remote, ancient mountain villages. It ticks a lot of boxes.

I deliberately paired my Naxos roadtrip with a few days in Santorini, where I stayed in a mind-blowing cave hotel, experienced the beauty and insanity of Oia, and explored the (less insane) rest of the island.

I was looking for a very different experience, then, in Naxos‚Äîbeautiful beaches, diverse architecture and history, delicious and unexpected cuisine, and the chance to feel like I was getting real, quiet glimpses into local culture rather than just a tourist‚Äôs idea of Greece.

You‚Äôll find something for everyone here, from solo travelers like myself, to couples, families young children, friend groups, or multigenerational. So my goal with this post is to do a super deep-dive into the island and then show you all the amazing things to do in Naxos on your epic roadtrip!

How this post is structured:

Why should you visit Naxos?

Where to stay in Naxos

What to wear/pack

How to get to the island

Getting around: do I need to rent a car? + driving

Things to see in Naxos (what to do on your roadtrip)

You might also like: 20+ Tips to Survive (& Thrive) on a Long Flight

Why visit Naxos?

Let‚Äôs start with just a few of the many reasons that Naxos is worth a visit:

Naxos is a melting pot of Mediterranean cultures‚Ä¶from Thracians to Ionians, to Romans and Venetians, you‚Äôll see the millennia of history, as the island has been at the center of Cycladic life since 4000 BCE.

Naxos has (arguably) the best traditional sand beaches in the Cyclades, with golden sand and sparkling azure waters.

It‚Äôs easy to rent a car and get around.

It‚Äôs also one of the most affordable destinations in the Greek isles, meaning you can frequently find high-end hotels at prices that feel like a bargain.

Unlike other Greek islands, Naxos has an unhurried pace and never feels crowded or busy.

It‚Äôs got great food and cocktails, including an up-and-coming foodie scene.

The island is more green and mountainous than you‚Äôd expect (it somewhat resembles Crete), with enchanting mountain villages, Byzantine ruins, fields, and sheep paired with the beauty of its beaches.

It‚Äôs a very popular walking or hiking destination, with lots of trails winding throughout the island.

Let‚Äôs tease out a few of those things further. Naxos is the most fertile island in the Cyclades, looking quite lush (by Cycladic standards, as the island grouping is mostly dry and volcanic). You‚Äôve got plains of of olive trees, lemon trees, and grape vines, tree-covered hills and valleys, and quite a bit of agriculture‚ÄîNaxos provides a lot of Greece‚Äôs dairy and potatoes, and the island is very proud of both.

If you only stay in Naxos Town and don‚Äôt explore further, you‚Äôll miss the green, hilly interior and the enchanting ancient mountain villages sprinkled all over. Naxos is and always has been a cultural crossroads, with 5,000 years of history layered on top of each other.

A quick snapshot of the island‚Äôs impressive history‚Ä¶I‚Äôll skip the prehistoric and Neolithic times since I don‚Äôt have a lot of details but there is evidence here. Naxos flourished after 700 BC under the Ancient Greeks. then Romans ruled the island for about 600 years beginning in 338 BC. It became part of the Byzantine Empire from 362 AD to 1204. The Venetians ruled it from 1207 until the island fell in to the Ottoman rule in 1566, and they had it until 1831, when it was liberated by the Modern Greek State. That‚Äôs a LOT!

Is Naxos safe? Short answer, yes. Obviously things can happen anywhere, but Naxos is a quieter and less-touristy island, and you really get a sense of community and people looking out for each other. The crime rate is very low and locals are friendly and laidback. The island is a great destination for solo female travelers in particular.

You might also like: The Only Carry-On Suitcase You‚Äôll Need

How to plan your trip

In this section I‚Äôll talk about Naxos itinerary planning more broadly, including where to base yourself, accommodations, getting around, and more. Then we‚Äôll talk more about the various things to see in Naxos in the remainder of the post.

The biggest thing to know is that you don‚Äôt need a concrete itinerary‚Äîthis is not a ‚Äúplan out every minute of the day‚Äù type of destination. But it‚Äôs good to know that it‚Äôs quite a large island, so difficult to truly explore in a very short time. If you only have a day or two, you can focus in on a few things or consider taking a tour with a local.

You might also like: 9 Sunscreens I Swear by for Travel

Where to stay in Naxos

It‚Äôs always critical to consider where you base yourself. While you can reach most places within Naxos fairly easily, you still have to remember that you‚Äôre driving on winding, hilly, unfamiliar roads and so it‚Äôs nice to stay somewhere fairly close in order to minimize driving times.

I stayed in two different hotels in Naxos, and would strongly recommend both. The first was Hotel Grotta, which was great‚Äîoverlooking the ocean in Naxos town, with gorgeous views, wonderful hospitality, good food, and a 5-minute walk into town.

The other was the unique luxury ELaiolithos, the only hotel located up in the mountains. The location and views were amazing, and the hotel uses only local materials, food, and drink. You get such an interesting experience here including the owner Helen‚Äôs hospitality, it‚Äôs absolutely worth a stay.

Read my guide for where to stay in Naxos!

You might also like: Everything You Need to Pack for a Beach Vacay

What to wear in Naxos (your packing list)

I visited Naxos in late September and it still definitely felt like summer, though got a bit chilly at night with the wind. My first two days on the island (when I was in Naxos Town) were SO WINDY (it made dresses difficult). But then once I was inland more, the wind died down.

I wore a good mixture of lightweight, breathable, stretchy pants and tops. Personally I‚Äôd skip jeans (too heavy and take up packing space).

My go-to travel pants are from Athleta, and the exact style that works for me is their Brooklyn Ankle Pant, specifically these ones.

These ones and these ones are two new travel pant favorites as well, super comfy and the fit is good on my body type.

I definitely wore sundresses once the wind died down, though. I‚Äôve had excellent luck with StitchFix in the past few years, though prefer to pick my own out vs. use the personal shopper option.

Amazon is a great option for all sorts of styles, and a really good return process (which is KEY!). Some good styles would be a t-shirt dress, a tank dress, or something flowy with fluttery cap sleeves.

Flowy skirts (like this) or long flowy dresses (like this, this and this) are perfect as well.

I‚Äôm not really a sun hat person and it would be less helpful in windy Naxos Town, but if you‚Äôre doing a lot of walking/hiking inland, it‚Äôs a good idea. While I didn‚Äôt feel as hot (due to the wind), I had to be more careful of the sun‚Ä¶good sunscreen was a must (I‚Äôm newly obsessed with this natural tallow sunscreen!), as were polarized sunglasses!

You‚Äôll want comfortable and stable shoes for walking up and down the slippery and often-uneven stones of Naxos Chora. My constant companions are these Rockport ones, which balance comfort/cushioning and cuteness (party in the front, biz in the back).

Aerosoles are my #1 go-to for really cute but still comfy sandals if I don‚Äôt need massive cushioning (a style like this for instance). Other great brands I‚Äôve found are Naturalizers (like these) and Vionics (like these or these), and these Aerothotics are a really good and very affordable option.

I spent a ton of time in my Olukai sneakers on this trip as well, specifically these Pehuea Li ones!

I also had my Rothy‚Äôs with me for walking around the towns (and for flights)

Don‚Äôt forget a good swimsuit, a headband (clutch for keeping windy hair out of your chapstick), a good face moisturizer, and I always have my fave clean makeup (which does great in sweaty weather)!

You might also like: 15+ Tips to Avoid (& Survive) Air Travel Woes

How to get to Naxos

There are two main ways to get to Naxos‚Äîby ferry or plane. I arrived by ferry and left by plane, so will speak to both briefly below.

Naxos is connected to Paros, Ios, and Santorini by ferry routes year-round, with a lot more sailing times during the high season. I recommend a fast ferry, and the travel times between them will vary from 45 minutes (Paros to Naxos) and 2 hours. Naxos also has regular ferry connections to Amorgos and Mykonos.

I took the ferry from Santorini, which takes about an hour and a half. I took the PowerJet ferry by Sea Jets, which cost ‚Ç¨55, and booked using FerryHopper, which was super easy (and then I could access my ticket on their app). I‚Äôd book ahead of time during peak season, to be safe.

It‚Äôs a huge clean boat with plenty of seating, food options, and more. You‚Äôll stow your luggage upon entering the boat (a few people with small amounts of hand luggage chose not to), then spend the time in your assigned seat or walking around (or finding an open seat elsewhere). I don‚Äôt find this type of boat to have a lot of motion/rough seas issues, but I‚Äôm sure it can on occasion.

You can also reach Naxos by ferry from Athens, which will take between 2.5 hours and 6 hours depending on which port and ship.

You might also like: 25+ Awesome Gift Ideas for the Traveler in Your Life

Alternatively, you can fly. I believe all flights will connect through Athens (though don‚Äôt quote me on that), which certainly adds time and steps to your trip if you‚Äôre hopping islands, but if you‚Äôre moving between island groups that definitely may be your best bet.

There are several daily flights to and from Athens, and the Naxos airport is super tiny. It‚Äôs very informal, there are two ticket counters, and the line is out the door when a flight is coming up. I didn‚Äôt have to take anything out of my bag going through security.

They do weigh bags (or at least checked them, not sure if they would have caused an issue). Once you get through security, you go sit in a little waiting area and then walk out to the plan. Sadly they did leave my suitcase in Naxos (I had wine in it so could‚Äôt carry on)‚Ä¶this was the first trip I had with my AirTags and boy was I glad to have them!

You might also like: Travel FAQ: Things You Might Not Know About Your Credit Card

Do I need to rent a car in Naxos?

Short answer, yes! The question of how to get around Naxos is fairly simple‚Ä¶if you‚Äôre planning on a Naxos roadtrip, you definitely need a car. If you‚Äôre only going to spend time in Naxos Town, then you don‚Äôt need one.

This post was already getting super long so I‚Äôve written a deeper post on renting a car and driving in Naxos. Be aware that the majority of cars will be manual transmission (stick shift), so you‚Äôll have to work a little harder to find an automatic and they‚Äôll get booked up earlier.

I always recommend searching on a few different rental car aggregators‚Ä¶my favorites currently are DiscoverCars and RentalCars, and AutoEurope (I often have better luck with the first two, but always check all three).

You might also like: My Favorite Face Sunscreens & Moisturizers for Travel

Driving in Naxos

Again, I‚Äôve written a deeper post talking about driving in Naxos, so will just mention a few things here. Mostly, the driving is completely doable‚Äîif quite hilly and winding. Naxos makes a great roadtrip destination.

The highways are in good shape and easy to navigate, but I did end up on a number of really bad rock and dirt roads.

Go slowly on those types of roads and be super careful with your tires. I grew up on gravel roads so am familiar with the driving and how to react if you start to fishtail, but if you‚Äôve never driven that just make sure you‚Äôre a confident driver.

Google Maps worked on the island, but it‚Äôs important to realize that it doesn‚Äôt necessarily differentiate between the good highways or the somewhat harrowing narrow gravel roads with hairpin turns. You may have to backtrack on occasion if you don‚Äôt like a particular road you‚Äôre on.

Gas stations are full service (I always tipped a bit). I really recommend not getting low on gas, because there‚Äôs not always a gas station close by. Navigating the island is pretty easy overall, but often the signs are only in Greek and don‚Äôt tell you how far away you are from the destination. Having Google Maps is a helpful backup.

Here are other posts on Naxos to help you plan your trip!

How to Spend a Day or Two in Naxos Town (Chora)

Where To Stay In Naxos, Greece: The Best Beach & Mountain Hotels

A Guide to Renting a Car & Driving in Naxos

Review: Staying At The Unique ELaiolithos Luxury Retreat

Exploring Rina Cave On The Perfect Naxos Boat Trip

An Accidental, Awesome Discovery of Agios Mamas In Naxos

Views For Days: Why You Have To Visit Rotonda Restaurant in Naxos

Greece Food Diary: 20+ Of The Best Greek Foods To Try

Things to do in Naxos on your roadtrip

As I mentioned above, Naxos is a large island so it can be difficult to try and see everything in a very short time. I had three full days plus bits of others, and felt like I really got a good feel for things.

That included about half a day in Naxos Town, a half-day boat tour, and a couple full days of driving the coasts and mountain villages. I didn‚Äôt spend time just laying out at the beach, but you should factor that in if you want to.

I had cell signal throughout most of the island, except in the southwest near Agiassos Beach, occasionally in the mountains, and in the southeast near Panermos Beach.

Speaking of beaches, the best ones are generally on the west coast, and they are usually prettier, quieter, and have better sand the farther south you travel. The more remote southeast coast is also stunning and note remotely crowded. One tip: if a beach is described as ‚Äúorganized,‚Äù that generally means it has sunbeds and umbrellas available to rent, and plentiful restaurants.

If you‚Äôre tight on time, consider a small group or private guided tour that can help you sample some of the island‚Äôs best sights with a local guide. I‚Äôll also shout out one thing I wanted to do‚Äîa food tour through the villages.

You might also like: A Travel Bucket List for Your 30s

Dive into Naxos Town

I first saw a photo of Naxos Chora on Pinterest, and immediately fell in love with that iconic view of whitewashed buildings piled atop a hill at the end of a narrow path, surrounded by sparkling blue water.

Chora (or Naxos Town) is the island‚Äôs capital, main port, and largest town (about 6,500 people). It makes a great base for exploring the island, with plenty of accommodation options (I stayed at the lovely Hotel Grotta), beautiful beaches, rich history, and a great food and cocktail scene.

You‚Äôll find nice beaches all over Naxos, including a few in the Chora‚Ä¶the ones in town are good-not-great, but are very easily accessible and one of them is quite kid-friendly. Agios Giorgos and Agios Prokopios are both family-friendly, while Grotta Beach is rocky with more intense waves and wind. There are also myriad day sail trips to choose from, all leaving from the waterfront.

Read (lots) more about what to do & where to eat in Naxos Town!

Other Greek adventures to help you plan your trip!

Things To Do In Oia (& ‚ÄúIs Oia Worth Visiting?‚Äù)

Santorini Beyond Oia: A Roadtrip Exploring The Island

Sampling The Delights Of Santorini‚Äôs Wineries

Santorini At Sunrise: Solo Hiking From Imerovigli To Oia

Where To Stay In Santorini: Oia‚Äôs Gorgeous Charisma Suites (or Art Maisons Aspaki)

How to Make the Most of a Half-Day In Athens

Why You Shouldn‚Äôt Skip Panagia Kapnikarea, A Hidden Gem in Athens

I spent two nights here, but really only about half a day exploring the town. Climb the narrow, jumbled streets to find the ruined Venetian castle. Browse the Old Town‚Äôs souvenir shops. Find an awesome rooftop bar to sip a cocktail made with local kitron liqueur.

And, of course, wander the ancient ruins of the Portara. This 2,500-year-old partially-constructed doorway is gorgeous any time of day, including with the sun sparkling on the turquoise waters. But it‚Äôs especially amazing at sunset.

You might also like: My Favorite Makeup Brand For Travel (& It‚Äôs Clean, Non-Toxic, Paleo, & More!)

Head inland & explore the mountain villages

So now let‚Äôs get that roadtrip started! My first stop was unplanned, I just saw the sign and decided to check it out.

I rolled up to the Monastery of Agios Ioannis Chryssostomos (John Chrysostom) and realized it didn‚Äôt open til 10:00am, so instead ate my donuts and sipped my coffee while soaking in the view.

You might also like: Travel FAQ: How to Pay for Things Overseas & Other Travel Money Tips

Then I stopped briefly at the tiny Chapel of Agios Ioannis Theologos, a tiny church built into the granite cliff that boasts breathtaking views of the Aegean Sea and the neighboring islands. I wouldn‚Äôt go out of your way to stop here if you‚Äôre on a tight timeline, but it‚Äôs a charming very short stop.

I think the light would be better for photograph at sunrise, or in the late afternoon.

You might also like: How to Make Any Itinerary At Least a Little Epic

Then I headed inland to explore the many charming mountain villages of Naxos. I started with a stop at the Eggares Olive Press Museum. Naxos is full of olive groves, and this is where you can learn more about the olive harvesting process and how they make and use the oil.

It‚Äôs a very small museum, basically one room and then a gift shop with a tasting table. The musuem features one of Naxos‚Äôs oldest remaining olive mills, from at least the late 1800s. Our young guide took us through the museum‚Äôs few exhibits, explaining the processes and the island‚Äôs long history with the olive tree.

Naxos claims to have the world‚Äôs oldest olive tree (our young guide said it was 6,300 years old)‚Ä¶I can neither confirm nor deny! But they are *obsessed* with olive oil here, always using it in lieu of butter.

In fact, he said they even baptize babies in olive oil‚Ä¶because it makes them slippery so the devil can‚Äôt touch them üôÇ The tour is free, though you‚Äôre welcome to tip. You can also do a bit of shopping and taste some olive-based products, including semi-candied olives with yogurt and honey (the olives are boiled in sugar & cinnamon water).

This is a nice 30-minute stop, but I‚Äôd consider it skippable if you‚Äôre tight on time.

You might also like: 10 Places I‚Äôm Dying to Visit in 2023

Nearby to Eggares is the village of Damalas, where you‚Äôll find a traditional pottery workshop. I wasn‚Äôt able to detour and visit, but had read ahead of time that if you catch the ceramist when he‚Äôs working, you can watch and he‚Äôll explain the process (some Naxos tours stop here).

I mention this at the beginning, but sometimes Google Maps doesn‚Äôt quite get you where you‚Äôre hoping. I‚Äôd searched for the ‚ÄúMelanes blue dome church‚Äù. Honestly I‚Äôm not positive whether I got there or not, but I DID end up here in the general vicinity with this view (despite a slightly difficult drive). So‚Ä¶#winning??

As a side note, Melanes is one of the oldest villages on the island and is the start and ending point for a very cool loop walk to Myli to the Kouroi of Flerio and back. It‚Äôs supposed to be a beautiful walk, easy to do, and takes about 2-3 hours. You can see a detailed recounting of this walk from EarthTrekkers.

You might also like: 11 of My Best Tips for ANY Trip

While I had specific destinations in mind a lot of the time, it‚Äôs important to also just‚Ä¶drive. Take random side roads that look cool, stop and take pictures of little chapels on the side of the road.

Think about your time here less in terms of just the ‚Äúthings to do in Naxos‚Äù. The beauty of having your own car is that you can explore the little nooks and crannies.

You might also like: 10 Things You Have to Do Before Every Trip

After maybe-or-maybe-not finding the blue dome church of Melanes, I went to try and find the Temple of Demeter. This was another fail for me. I searched for it on Google Maps and somehow it got confused. It took me to this spot where I walked a bit and realized I was in the wrong place.

This is what it should look like. What you see below is NOT it. The Temple of Demeter dates back to 530 BCE and is scenically located on a hilltop above the village of Kastri. It‚Äôs a nice spot to wander the marble ruins and admire the panoramic views. It should be on your way to the southwest-side beaches.

You might also like: My All-Time Favorite Bra for Travel

From here I spent the rest of the day stopping in the mountain villages and wandering around. I‚Äôve posted a real deep-dive on the villages and what to see and do there. For the sake of time and space I‚Äôm not going to go into as much detail here, so I definitely recommend checking out the other post.

Instead I‚Äôll do more of a high-level overview of the coolest towns. I‚Äôm going in a generally-logical order below, but you can ping-pong between them for the most part (the distances are relatively small)‚Ä¶I think I ended up visiting Chalki like three separate times.

And in fact, we‚Äôll start with Chalkio! You may also see it spelled Halki or Chalki, or probably like seven other names. Whether you‚Äôre sipping a drink outside a little cafe, devouring a slice of galaktoboureko, meandering through the narrow alleyways, shopping for locally-made crafts, or sipping kitron liqueur. it‚Äôs a must-see.

I tried walking to the church of of Agios Giorgios Diasoritis, but I either did it wrong or just got impatient (I think the latter?). Supposedly it‚Äôs just a 10-minute walk from the village, and I was following other people on the same mission‚Ä¶we walked past some old olive trees and a different church, then I finally turned back because I was tight on time. This church is where I was supposed to end up.

If you‚Äôre able to swing it (I recommend staying at nearby ELaiolithos), Chalki really shines in the late afternoon/early evening once the day tripper crowds have gone! She recommended dinner at Paravas, which is a super cool spot. I had saganaki, moussaka, traditional Naxian potatoes with graviera cheese, and some Greek wine.

Follow One Girl, Whole World on Pinterest for more travel tips & inspiration!

The main thing you‚Äôll hear people talk about when it comes to Chalki is that it‚Äôs where the local liquor, kitron, is distilled. You can tour the Kitron Distillery if you‚Äôre so inclined. Mine was a self-guided tour through a few rooms. As someone who has toured a lot of distilleries and knows the general process, it wouldn‚Äôt be high on my list.

But you definitely need to *taste* kitron! I had a cocktail with kitron while in Naxos Town, but here I tried to get kitron ice cream next door to the distillery‚Ä¶sadly they were out.

If you‚Äôre doing a tour of Naxos instead of a self-driving roadtrip, you might consider doing a private tour and having them go to Chalkio but personally I‚Äôd skip the distillery.

You might also like: Why This Carry-On Suitcase Is My Life Partner

Okay, moving on. I loved the views of villages from the road as I was driving‚Ä¶I definitely had to stop to snap a pic!

You might also like: How to Pick the Right Flight Every Time

Next up is the town of Filoti. It‚Äôs only 2km down the road from Chalki, but I didn‚Äôt spend as much time here (mostly because I had a bit more trouble finding parking). Filoti is the largest village in Tragea Valley, so has lots of good options for taverns, restaurants, and apartment rentals.

And if you climb and wind your way your way up the hill from the main road, you‚Äôll find a tight, steep maze of paths and alleys that are perfect for wandering without a destination in mind.

Make sure to catch the incredibly photogenic white marble church, Panagia Filotissia (Virgin Mary of Filoti), toward the top of the town.

You might also like: How I Plan Trips: My Detailed Process

I was thoroughly charmed by all the kitties of Naxos (though they prefer to be admired from afar).

From Filoti, the natural next stop for me was Apeiranthos. One note‚ÄîI think the views and pullouts are even better the opposite direction, so going from from Apiranthos toward Chalki.

But first I wanted to stop at Rotonda, a cafe and restaurant with stunning views. I‚Äôve written a separate post on this lovely spot, which is a must-visit in your Naxos mountain village explorations, as long as the weather is nice (and it would be great at sunset!).

I had a late lunch and a glass of local wine while enjoying the view, then continued on toward Apeiranthos.

One other thing that‚Äôs in this general vicinity is the starting point to hike to the top of Mount Zeus, the highest point of the Cyclades. Naxos‚Äô most famous hike starts at ‚ÄúAria Spring‚Äù and is supposed to take an hour and a half. I didn‚Äôt end up doing any hiking while on Naxos, but it‚Äôs a very popular pasttime.

You might also like: 13 Cool Souvenir Ideas To Pick Up While Traveling

Apeiranthos is definitely a must-visit on your Naxos roadtrip! The town‚Äôs name means ‚Äúplenty of flowers‚Äù, and it‚Äôs a beautiful STEEP little village full of little alleyways and paved walking paths. For the most part you park on the edge of town and then walk into/up into the main town area.

I feel like I didn‚Äôt really explore the town as much as I‚Äôd have liked to. There are lots of beautiful viewpoints, some good souvenir shopping, and an old wood bakery (a dying art) that is supposedly there, which I forgot to look for.

All the marble-paved alleys and white buildings make the town just sparkle.

You might also like: How To Plan A Trip: Important Questions To Guide You

From Apiranthos, you could next continue east through Koronos, and north to the small harbor village of Apollonas, then take the northwest coastal road back to Naxos Chora (if that‚Äôs where you‚Äôre staying).

We‚Äôll get there eventually, but for tonight we‚Äôre wrapping up and checking into our amazing hotel. I‚Äôve got lots of beautiful seaside towns and beaches to show you next.

You might also like: 7 Travel Intentions for 2023

Before we wrap up our main mountain villages, here are the ones I‚Äôd hoped to visit and didn‚Äôt get to:

Melanes

Koronos

Kaloritsa Cave Monastery‚Ä¶about 15 minute walk from Timios Stavros Monastery

Flerio

Right near Chalki and Filoti and literally a minute from ELaiolithos is the famous Panagia Drosiani Church, Naxos‚Äôs oldest Christian church (from about the 6th century). It‚Äôs worth a quick stop.

You might also like: Tips for Choosing the Best Rental or Hotel Every Time

As I‚Äôve mentioned a few times in this post, for the second half of my Naxos roadtrip, I stayed at the unique ELaiolithos Luxury Resort. This is the only hotel in the mountains, and is a ‚Äúgreen‚Äù luxury hotel run by local Helen Marakis, blending sustainability and hospitality.

She lovingly chose every single element of the hotel‚Äôs design and d√©cor, and all the materials and food are using local Naxian materials and artists‚Äîit‚Äôs basically a love letter to the island! Helen is so welcoming and treats you more like family, inviting you into her life.

The hotel is nestled into the mountains, with a gorgeous sunset view and SO much peace and quiet (except the occasional distant clang of the goat bells). The breakfast is amazing, cocktails are great, and the rooms spacious and comfortable. I highly recommend a stay here! While it‚Äôs luxury, I found the price still very affordable.

Read my deeper review of staying at ELaiolithos Luxury Retreat here!

You might also like: The 10 Best Books I Read in 2022

Before we head to the coast, there are two other spots I want to mention. I made a fairly short visit to Saint Anna Winery, and was so happy I did!

It‚Äôs tiny and charming, and I was welcomed warmly by the winemaker‚Äôs mom. I tasted a few wines (which were great but I didn‚Äôt have room in my luggage), and bought a tiny bottle of their sweet white and their grappa (made with cinnamon and spices).
